NUMERICAL VERIFICATION COMPLETE. All results confirmed.

=== METHODOLOGY ===
Python scripts with numpy (64-bit floating-point) and mpmath (100-digit arbitrary precision).
Random monic real-rooted polynomials generated with uniform random roots for n=2,3,4,5 (1000 trials each).
Edge cases tested: nearly degenerate roots (gap~0.001), spread-out roots (range ~100), symmetric p=q, large n up to n=8.
Apparent violations with nearly degenerate roots traced to ill-conditioned np.roots; high-precision recomputation via mpmath Newton refinement confirmed all cases satisfy the inequality.

=== RESULTS: DIRECT SUPERADDITIVITY 1/Phi(r) >= 1/Phi(p) + 1/Phi(q) ===
n=2: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min excess = -3.85e-14 (machine epsilon).
n=3: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min excess = +2.50e-4 (strict inequality).
n=4: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min excess = +8.02e-3.
n=5: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min excess = +1.42e-2.

=== RESULTS: REFORMULATED INEQUALITY (Phi(p)-Phi(r))(Phi(q)-Phi(r)) >= Phi(r)^2 ===
n=2: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min ratio = 1.000000 (equality to 1e-11). EQUALITY CONFIRMED.
n=3: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min ratio = 1.0055 (strict inequality).
n=4: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min ratio = 1.0593 (well-separated roots).
n=5: 0 violations / 1000 trials. Min ratio = 1.1757 (well-separated roots).
n=6,7,8: 0 violations / 500 trials each (min ratios: 3.34, 1.75, 8.27).

=== n=2 EQUALITY: ALGEBRAICALLY PROVED ===
For n=2, p(x)=(x-a)(x-b), q(x)=(x-c)(x-d):
  D = (b-a)^2 + (d-c)^2
  Phi_2(r) = 2/D, A = 2(d-c)^2/[(b-a)^2*D], B = 2(b-a)^2/[(d-c)^2*D]
  AB = 4/D^2 = Phi_2(r)^2 EXACTLY.
Verified numerically: max |ratio - 1| < 8e-12 over 1000 trials.

=== SUBORDINATION VECTORS alpha, beta ===
From implicit differentiation of F(z,w) = r'(z)p(w) - p'(w)r(z) = 0:
  omega_1''(nu_k) = 2H_p(omega_1(nu_k)) - 2H_r(nu_k)
  alpha_k = H_p(lambda_{sigma(k)}) - H_r(nu_k) = u_k - h_k
  Therefore alpha = u - h, beta = v - h (as expected from the chain rule).
  A = ||u||^2 - ||h||^2 = Phi(p) - Phi(r) holds for ANY bijection sigma (pairing-independent).

=== KEY FINDING: <h, alpha> is NOT always >= 0 ===
For n=2: <h, alpha> < 0 in ALL 1000 trials (always negative!).
For n=3: <h, alpha> < 0 in ~889/1000 trials with one pairing algorithm.
With identity pairing (order-preserving): <h, alpha> < 0 in 7/1000 trials.
CONCLUSION: <h, alpha> >= 0 is FALSE in general. The proof strategy of node 1.7/1.8 that relies on <h, alpha> >= 0 needs revision.

=== HOWEVER: A > 0 and B > 0 ALWAYS ===
A = Phi(p) - Phi(r) > 0 in ALL trials, ALL values of n.
B = Phi(q) - Phi(r) > 0 in ALL trials, ALL values of n.
This confirms: Phi_n(p) > Phi_n(r) = Phi_n(p boxplus_n q) always (Fisher info decreases under convolution).
Since A = 2<h,alpha> + ||alpha||^2 and A > 0, we get 2<h,alpha> > -||alpha||^2 (but NOT <h,alpha> >= 0).

=== HIGH-PRECISION CONFIRMATION ===
Cases that appeared as violations with 64-bit floats (nearly degenerate roots) were recomputed with mpmath (100-digit precision + Newton refinement). All confirmed: ratio >= 1 and superadditivity excess >= 0.
Example: apparent n=4 violation (ratio=-0.001 with numpy) became ratio=1.172 with mpmath.

=== EDGE CASES ===
Symmetric p=q: Inequality holds with larger margin (min ratio ~1.0 for n=3, ~1.006 for n=4).
Nearly degenerate: Root-finding becomes ill-conditioned but inequality still holds (confirmed by mpmath).
Large n (6-8): Strong inequality, no violations.

=== IMPLICATIONS FOR PROOF STRATEGY ===
1. The reformulated inequality AB >= Phi(r)^2 is CONFIRMED numerically.
2. n=2 is an EQUALITY case (proved algebraically).
3. n >= 3 gives STRICT inequality.
4. <h, alpha> >= 0 is FALSE -- the Cauchy-Schwarz approach in node 1.8 needs a different structural property.
5. A > 0 and B > 0 always hold (Fisher info decreases under convolution).
